natural problem: Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "P = {x. \<exists> a b. x = 10 * a + b \<or> x = 10 * b + a, a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6}}"
and h1 : "card P = 11"
and h2 : "card {x. \<exists> a b. x = 10 * a + b \<or> x = 10 * b + a, a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 20} = 11"
shows  "measure (count_space {x. x \<in> P}) {x. x \<in> P \<and> 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 20} = 11/36"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "P = {x. \<exists> a b. x = 10 * a + b \<or> x = 10 * b + a, a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6}}"
and h1 : "card P = 11"
and h2 : "card {x. \<exists> a b. x = 10 * a + b \<or> x = 10 * b + a, a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 20} = 11"
shows  "measure (count_space {x. x \<in> P}) {x. x \<in> P \<and> 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 20} = 11/36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider all the two-digit numbers that can be formed by using the digits 1 through 6. If there are 11 such numbers between 10 and 20, what is the probability that a randomly chosen two-digit number formed by using the digits 1 through 6 lies between 10 and 20 (inclusive)? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dice1 dice2 :: nat and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "dice1 \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "dice2 \<in> {1..6}"
and h2 : "prob = (card {n. n \<in> {10..20} \<and> (n = 10 * dice1 + dice2 \<or> n = 10 * dice2 + dice1)}) / 36"
shows  "prob = 11 / 36"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes dice1 dice2 :: nat and prob :: real
assumes h0 : "dice1 \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "dice2 \<in> {1..6}"
and h2 : "prob = (card {n. n \<in> {10..20} \<and> (n = 10 * dice1 + dice2 \<or> n = 10 * dice2 + dice1)}) / 36"
shows  "prob = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A pair of fair six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the product of the two numbers rolled is between 10 and 20, inclusive? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum>(x, y) \<in> {(x, y). 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 6}. if 10 \<le> (10 * x + y) \<and> (10 * x + y) \<le> 20 \<or> 10 \<le> (10 * y + x) \<and> (10 * y + x) \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "prob = 11 / 36"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Sum>(x, y) \<in> {(x, y). 1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 6}. if 10 \<le> (10 * x + y) \<and> (10 * x + y) \<le> 20 \<or> 10 \<le> (10 * y + x) \<and> (10 * y + x) \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "prob = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Two dice are rolled and their faces are labeled with numbers from 1 to 6. What is the probability that the two-digit numbers formed by their faces (in both possible orders) are between 10 and 20, inclusive? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "rat set"
assumes h0 : "P = { p/q | p q. p \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<and> q \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> (10 \<le> p*10 + q \<and> p*10 + q \<le> 20 \<or> 10 \<le> q*10 + p \<and> q*10 + p \<le> 20)}"
shows  "card P = 11" and "frac (card P) 36 = 11 / 36"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "rat set"
assumes h0 : "P = { p/q | p q. p \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<and> q \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} \<and> p \<noteq> q \<and> (10 \<le> p*10 + q \<and> p*10 + q \<le> 20 \<or> 10 \<le> q*10 + p \<and> q*10 + p \<le> 20)}"
shows  "card P = 11" and "frac (card P) 36 = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider all fractions of the form $\frac{p}{q}$, where $p$ and $q$ are distinct integers from the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$, and either $10 \leq 10p + q \leq 20$ or $10 \leq 10q + p \leq 20$. How many such fractions are there, and what is the ratio of this count to the total possible fractions? The final answers are 11 and $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real and A B :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "A = {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 20 \<and> (\<exists>i j. n = i * 10 + j) \<and> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6}"
and h1 : "B = {n. (\<exists>i j. n = i * 10 + j) \<and> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6}"
and h2 : "p = card A / card B"
shows  "p = 11 / 36"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real and A B :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "A = {n. 10 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 20 \<and> (\<exists>i j. n = i * 10 + j) \<and> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6}"
and h1 : "B = {n. (\<exists>i j. n = i * 10 + j) \<and> 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> j \<and> j \<le> 6}"
and h2 : "p = card A / card B"
shows  "p = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a 6x6 grid, each cell contains a number formed by the product of its row and column numbers multiplied by 10 plus the sum of its row and column numbers. Let set A consist of all the numbers in the grid between 10 and 20 inclusive, and set B consist of all the numbers in the grid. What is the probability that a randomly chosen number from set B belongs to set A? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and num_success :: int and num_total :: int
assumes h0 : "num_success = 11"
and h1 : "num_total = 36"
and h2 : "probability x = num_success / num_total"
and h3 : "x \<in> {10..20}"
shows  "probability x = 11 / 36"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and num_success :: int and num_total :: int
assumes h0 : "num_success = 11"
and h1 : "num_total = 36"
and h2 : "probability x = num_success / num_total"
and h3 : "x \<in> {10..20}"
shows  "probability x = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A probability function is defined as the ratio of successful outcomes to total outcomes. If there are 11 successful outcomes out of 36 total outcomes, find the probability of an event $x$ occurring, where $x$ is between 10 and 20. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>d1 \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum>d2 \<in> {1..6}. (if (10 \<le> 10 * d1 + d2 \<and> 10 * d1 + d2 \<le> 20) \<or> (10 \<le> 10 * d2 + d1 \<and> 10 * d2 + d1 \<le> 20) then 1 else 0)) / 36"
shows  "p = 11 / 36"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>d1 \<in> {1..6}. \<Sum>d2 \<in> {1..6}. (if (10 \<le> 10 * d1 + d2 \<and> 10 * d1 + d2 \<le> 20) \<or> (10 \<le> 10 * d2 + d1 \<and> 10 * d2 + d1 \<le> 20) then 1 else 0)) / 36"
shows  "p = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Two fair six-sided dice, each with faces numbered 1 through 6, are rolled. What is the probability that the two-digit number formed by the dice (with the first die showing the tens digit and the second die showing the units digit) or the two-digit number formed by reversing the digits is between 10 and 20, inclusive? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> (i, j) \<in> ({1..6} \<times> {1..6}). if (10 \<le> (10 * i + j) \<and> (10 * i + j) \<le> 20) \<or> (10 \<le> (10 * j + i) \<and> (10 * j + i) \<le> 20) then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "P = 11 / 36"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> (i, j) \<in> ({1..6} \<times> {1..6}). if (10 \<le> (10 * i + j) \<and> (10 * i + j) \<le> 20) \<or> (10 \<le> (10 * j + i) \<and> (10 * j + i) \<le> 20) then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "P = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the probability that the sum of two numbers rolled on a pair of standard 6-sided dice is between 10 and 20, inclusive, when the numbers are combined as either $10i+j$ or $10j+i$. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>(x,y)\<in>{(x,y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> (10 \<le> 10 * x + y \<and> 10 * x + y \<le> 20) \<or> (10 \<le> 10 * y + x \<and> 10 * y + x \<le> 20)}. 1) / 36"
shows  "p = 11 / 36"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum>(x,y)\<in>{(x,y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> (10 \<le> 10 * x + y \<and> 10 * x + y \<le> 20) \<or> (10 \<le> 10 * y + x \<and> 10 * y + x \<le> 20)}. 1) / 36"
shows  "p = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: What is the probability of obtaining a two-digit number between 10 and 20 (inclusive) when choosing two digits from 1 to 6 and placing them side by side in any order? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "setsum (\<lambda>i. setsum (\<lambda>j. if 10 \<le> 10 * i + j \<and> 10 * i + j \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) {1..6}) {1..6} = 11"
and h1 : "setsum (\<lambda>i. setsum (\<lambda>j. if 10 \<le> 10 * j + i \<and> 10 * j + i \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) {1..6}) {1..6} = 11"
shows  "((setsum (\<lambda>i. setsum (\<lambda>j. if 10 \<le> 10 * i + j \<and> 10 * i + j \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) {1..6}) {1..6}) +
(setsum (\<lambda>i. setsum (\<lambda>j. if 10 \<le> 10 * j + i \<and> 10 * j + i \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) {1..6}) {1..6})) / (6 * 6) = 11 / 36"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Melinda will roll two standard six-sided dice and make a two-digit number with the two numbers she rolls. For example, if she rolls a 6 and a 3, she can either form 36 or 63. What is the probability that she will be able to make an integer between 10 and 20, inclusive? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 She can do this if and only if at least one of the dice lands on a 1. The probability neither of the dice is a 1 is $\left(\frac{5}{6}\right) \left(\frac{5}{6}\right) = \frac{25}{36}$.
 So the probability at least one die is a 1 is $1-\frac{25}{36} = \boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "setsum (\<lambda>i. setsum (\<lambda>j. if 10 \<le> 10 * i + j \<and> 10 * i + j \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) {1..6}) {1..6} = 11"
and h1 : "setsum (\<lambda>i. setsum (\<lambda>j. if 10 \<le> 10 * j + i \<and> 10 * j + i \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) {1..6}) {1..6} = 11"
shows  "((setsum (\<lambda>i. setsum (\<lambda>j. if 10 \<le> 10 * i + j \<and> 10 * i + j \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) {1..6}) {1..6}) +
(setsum (\<lambda>i. setsum (\<lambda>j. if 10 \<le> 10 * j + i \<and> 10 * j + i \<le> 20 then 1 else 0) {1..6}) {1..6})) / (6 * 6) = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a 6x6 grid, there are 11 cells with values between 10 and 20 (inclusive) when calculated using both row-major and column-major order. What is the ratio of the number of these cells to the total number of cells in the grid? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.
